<!-- Explain, in a clear and concise way, the command you ran and the result you were trying to achieve.
Example: "I ran `spack find` to list all the installed packages and ..." -->

When I install within an environment a package XXX which depends on a package YYY which  is defined as external in the `spack.yaml`, the spec of the package YYY appears when doing  `spack find` (and what is more annoying, can cause 'conflicts' if a variant of the package XXX is actually built by spack in another context when doing 'spack load XXX').

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. clone and 'source' a fresh spack
2. unzip the provided archive in a directory DIR 
[spack-external-packages.zip](https://github.com/spack/spack/files/5143181/spack-external-packages.zip)
3. in `DIR/spack-env`, change `./` under the `repos` section to `DIR/spack-env` (relative path here does not seems to work)
4. in the directory DIR, do  `spack -e spack-env install foo`
5. `spack find`


### Information on your system
* **Spack:** 0.15.4-711-7dd58c7ed
* **Python:** 3.8.2
* **Platform:** linux-ubuntu20.04-skylake

### Additional information

<!-- These boxes can be checked by replacing [ ] with [x] or by clicking them after submitting the issue. -->
- [x] I have run `spack debug report` and reported the version of Spack/Python/Platform
- [ ] I have searched the issues of this repo and believe this is not a duplicate
- [ ] I have run the failing commands in debug mode and reported the output

title: Spec for external packages appears in 'spack find'
